text: Hey, so what was the commit magic word to prevent jenkins from building? skip-ci? skipci?
can anyone anyway please stop my job (1127)?
<@U0ZJZBJLF> I stopped build#1127
ty
you know the commit flag to make jenkins ignore?
provide [ci skip] in commit message
thanks
with the [ ] ?
yes
<@U2A98QJKS|nmpacheco> has joined the channel
<@U0UHG4VP1> <@U0KM61BCP> successful automated deployment of docker side
<https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage-sandbox/tags/>
ill work on cleaning this all up and bringing over the rest of the provisioning.sh stuff
sweet!
<@U0KM61BCP> <https://github.com/ghaskins/hyperledger-fabric-baseimage/commit/a73143819670117b03e246ac1de74c8d2375c0f4>
one question that remains:  should I rename the vagrant image to “hyperledger/fabric-devenv” and just make fabric.git/devenv/Vagrantfile simply reference it
its moving in a direction where its not really a “baseimage” but rather it is the full devenv
the other direction is I could back off some of the more fluid deps, like pip
leave this “baseimage”, and do that stuff in a pared down version of fabric.git/scripts/provision
<@U0KM61BCP>: may I turn on commit message line length enforcement, or is that too harsh?
<@U0UHG4VP1> - not too harsh IMHO
I actually like to know when I am lazy and violate it
<@U0PB67X4K> I agree. My concern is making the funnel too hard to enter for newbies, versus review overhead for committers. I don’t know where the setting should be

good point, but in this case probably easier for them to get an error when they submit a review telling them the limit then having them go back, alter the commit and resubmit?   I suppose its as they say "six one way, half a dozen the other"
well I won’t turn it on yet :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U0UHG4VP1> I think we should turn it on
<@U0KM61BCP> OK. I’ll do it tonight - it will take a short Gerrit outage to make it happen
I agree with <@U0PB67X4K> better to get it up front than have to resubmit the patch when a maintainer complains
if we get complaints we can always reconsider
<@U0UHG4VP1> could you add the "git parameter plugin" at earliest convenience
<@U0KPFAZNF> to the sandbox?
<@U0KPFAZNF> done
<@U0UHG4VP1> yes pls
Thx
ghaskins could I restart Jenkins quickly?
if you’re in the middle of editing somehting I’ll wait
Sure no
Np
Nope, all clear
should be done
Ty
I'm trying to find a way to trigger a Jenkins build if and only if there is a new git tag, FYI
So if you happen to know or stumble on something...
when would be good to take a short gerrit outage?
Now is fine for me, fwiw
well, it’s only 17:30 on the west coast, I think I’ll wait until after dinner
a tag is a ref, right? could you trigger on refs/tags/*?
Possibly
To be clear, it's fine for a git hook to kick Jenkins... What I would like is for Jenkins to only try if there is a new tag
Or, ignore the kicks when there isn't a new tag, really
<http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7805603/is-it-possible-for-jenkins-to-automatically-detect-and-build-newly-created-tags>

attachments.title: Is it possible for Jenkins to automatically detect and build newly created tags in a git repo?
attachments.text: It would be nice for our Jenkins CI server to automatically detect, deploy and build tags as they are created in our Github <http://repository.Is|repository.Is> this possible?
attachments.fallback: Is it possible for Jenkins to automatically detect and build newly created tags in a git repo?

text: <@U0UHG4VP1> you are talking about the two tiered trigger-build+tagged build solution?
<@U0KPFAZNF>: yeah
cool, that seems tenable
we could have one trigger job, and I envision 4 builders
(vagrant, docker-x86, docker-ppc, docker-z)
i suppose we might have to manually trigger all 4 from the trigger job, but that seems managable
next “unknown” is how to manage tags via gerrit
(I know part of the magic is using annotated tags, but we might have a learning curve getting it all working)
im thinking workflow is: someone submits an annotated tag for review…if it gets the requisite +2s, its merged, which kicks the trigger job, which flows down...
thoughts?
there would presumably be 1 or more other patches that flow through gerrit prior to the tag commit that actually change the logic
those shouldnt trigger the jobs that do the push, but we should have some kind of -verify job run on those
right now, I have 4 basic targets:  make vagrant|vagrant-local|docker|docker-local
the -local variants run the same logic as the non-local, except they dont push the image to atlas/dockerhub
so, the verify job could use those
I’ve never used tags in that way. I’ve always just laid the tags down
in my role as release engineer
I just tried pushing a tag for review, and it just took the tag: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=lf-sandbox.git;a=commit;h=de72c6e3ea837529a6bfb84fd63384d9738dbca2>
Hmm, maybe you have privs
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=lf-sandbox.git;a=tag;h=refs/tags/TEST_TAG> is more interesting
I'll try mine
:disappointed: <https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/repo-discuss/VV_xj6ftvoY>
